author: sukkergris
body:
# Steps to reproduce
Follow example 7 here: [ https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.management/new-item?view=powershell-7
```powershell](Link)!
1. Create a folder eg. named "power"
2. In this (power) folder create an empty folder named "Notice"
3. In this (power) folder create a file named "Notice.txt"
4. As admin run this script: 
New-Item -ItemType SymbolicLink -Path .\link -Target .\Notice
```

# Expected behavior

Functioning link to Notice named "link"

# Actual behavior

link not working

#Note
Working perfectly with absolute path and in cmd
cmd >mklink /d "./link2" "./Notice"

comments.author: KalleOlaviNiemitalo
comments.body:
I think it's the same bug as in #12785, i.e. caused by #8783, but more serious here because Windows supports relative symbolic links, unlike relative junctions.

As a workaround, start PowerShell in the desired directory, instead of using `Set-Location` within PowerShell. `New-Item -ItemType SymbolicLink` will then correctly create a relative symbolic link. This works with both directory symbolic links and file symbolic links.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
I'd expect two different PRs.
1. Bug - We should resolve and check absolute path here
https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/1f252f8bbaef5fafe534f611283fac5ad9d08a10/src/System.Management.Automation/namespaces/FileSystemProvider.cs#L2364
2. Enhancement - Since it is possible to create symbolic links to non-existing targets and default always is file symlink we should add new type SymbolicLinkDirectory to force creating link to directory.

comments.author: anthonyvdotbe
comments.body:
This issue occurs for me (though not always, and I don't understand yet when it does/doesn't) with v7.1.2 on Windows 10.0.19042.0.

Edit: I can consistently reproduce this by launching a Windows Sandbox, installing PowerShell 7.1.2 in it, and running the following 2 commands:
```
New-Item -ItemType Directory -Path target
New-Item -ItemType SymbolicLink -Path link -Value target
```
